abstract: Editorial opposes Georgia's sentencing of inmate Warren Lee Hill Jr to death for murdering fellow prisoner in 1991; holds that as an intellectually disabled person, Hill should be spared death penalty; notes Georgia's law requiring defendants to prove intellectual disability sets nearly impossible standard to meet; contends Hill's case spotlights faults inherent in capital punishment, and urges United States Supreme Court to intervene.
lead_paragraph: No other state has better embodied the full range of endless complications and contradictions of capital punishment.
snippet: No other state has better embodied the full range of endless complications and contradictions of capital punishment.
